primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores how Socially Engaged Buddhism has developed in response to global conversations on systemic oppression, climate justice, equity, decolonization, and trauma. We examine the roots of Engaged Buddhism in countries such as Vietnam, China & Taiwan, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and India, and its transformation into a global movement. Themes include Buddhist environmental activism, and Buddhist protest movements, along with research on the application of Buddhist teachings in healthcare, education, business, and the criminal justice system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Socially Engaged Buddhism

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the encounter between Buddhism and psychology over the last century, with cross-disciplinary study of topics such as self, embodiment, impermanence, suffering, liberation, and insight. We explore how (and why) scientists, psychologists, and Buddhist reformers have reinterpreted Buddhism as “science” and how Buddhist contemplative practices such as mindfulness or compassion training have been transformed and promoted by modern psychology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhism and Psychology

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of how mindfulness-based approaches are being used in biomedical mental health interventions. We study mindfulness from historical, societal, structural, cultural, professional, and personal perspectives, with an emphasis on its Buddhist foundations and on concepts of the embodied mind. We look at how recent socio-political phenomena are inspiring diverse applications and adaptations of mindfulness-based interventions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mindfulness-Informed Interventions for Mental Health

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

courses.name: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides a conceptual and contemplative interdisciplinary exploration of “wisdom traditions.” Buddhist approaches to self-actualization and wisdom will be compared to traditions from Mesopotamia, classical Greece, Christianity, the Renaissance, etc. Coursework includes guided experiential exercises for various traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science of Wisdom: Buddhist and Western Traditions

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor
Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of scientific research on the psychological and neurophysiological effects of meditation. We explore the effects of different meditation styles on brain structure, brain activity, neurochemistry and other biological processes. Effects of meditation on mental health, pain, social behavior, aging, memory, and cardiovascular function are also a major focus. The use of meditation in the treatment and prevention of illness is critically reviewed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Meditation and the Body

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

An interdisciplinary study of how well-being is understood both in the sciences and the humanities, considering how wellbeing and distress are social, cultural, political, spiritual, ecological, and historical phenomena. Experiential exercises will accompany each thematic topic.

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of mindfulness as a systematic investigation of subjective experience, with a survey of classic descriptions and contemporary scientific literature. Students will explore meditative practices in class and maintain a meditation practice outside class.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exploring Mindful Awareness
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW338H1, NEW432H1 (Advanced Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Cultivating Consciousness), offered in Fall 2012, Fall 2013, Fall 2014, Summer 2015, and Winter 2016

courses.name: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores teachings and principles in Buddhist canonical sources and considers their application to a wide range of social, political, and environmental crises we are facing today, including climate justice, systemic racism, burnout and mental health. We explore how Buddhist teachings are applied and adapted across different sectors of society including healthcare, education and business.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: NEW214Y1/ NEW336H1 (Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues), offered in Winter 2020 or Winter 2021/ BPM336H1 (Special Topics in Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues), offered in Winter 2022

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

courses.name: Advanced Exploration of Buddhist Psychology and Practice

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor
Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth, interdisciplinary exploration of how Buddhist teachings are set in conversation with contemporary scientific research on topics such as suffering, wellbeing, and compassion, through a mixture of lecture, textual analysis, discussion, and hands-on experiential practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Exploration of Buddhist Psychology and Practice

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health

subjectPost.name: Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor
Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health Minor

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

subjectPost.name: All

cmCourseInfo.description: An exponential increase of scientific research on aspects of Buddhist theories of mind and mindfulness meditation has contributed to the growing popularity of mindfulness across the sectors of healthcare, education and business. Examines the theoretical and empirical basis of mindfulness-based interventions and applications in healthcare settings and beyond. Critically addresses the roots of mindfulness, current models and adaptations, relevant applications, interventions and outcomes. Quantitative and qualitative research methodology will be reviewed, and conceptual, methodological, statistical, and interpretive limitations of the scientific literature will be discussed. The course aims to build scientific literacy skills through the assessment, critique, and discussion of peer reviewed journal articles.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mindfulness Meditation: Science and Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A statistics course (e.g. PSY201H1, SOC202H1, STA220H1)

subSections: New C-Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
